docs.lead_paragraph: The inconvenient truth is that most of the French are too comfortably off, despite 10 percent unemployment, to countenance radical changes to their way of life.

headline.main: French Are Too Comfortable to Consider Reform
headline.print_headline: French Are Too Comfortable to Consider Reform

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican Party’s de facto head of economic policy, may be one of its most important figures outside of Mitt Romney.

headline.seo: Paul Ryan’s Kinetic Rise in G.O.P.
headline.main: Ryan’s Rise From Follower to G.O.P. Trailblazer
headline.print_headline: Ryan’s Rise From Follower to G.O.P. Trailblazer

docs.abstract: Representative Paul D Ryan of Wisconsin, has become perhaps the most influential policy maker in the Republican Party, its de facto head of economic policy, intent on a fundamental transformation of the federal government; outside of Mitt Romney, Ryan may be the party’s most important figure; he is among the handful of people most often mentioned as both a 2012 vice-presidential nominee and a future presidential candidate (Series: The Ticket).
docs.snippet: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the Republican Party’s de facto head of economic policy, may be one of its most important figures outside of Mitt Romney.

docs.lead_paragraph: A broad anti-gay initiative in North Carolina threatens basic rights and ought to be watched closely nationwide.
docs.abstract: Editorial scores North Carolina's Republican-controlled Legislature for attempting to alter the State Constitution so that it explicitly bans same-sex marriage; contends that poorly-worded ballot measure would bar other legal arrangements like civil unions and domestic partnerships, imperiling some children's health insurance benefits.
docs.snippet: A broad anti-gay initiative in North Carolina threatens basic rights and ought to be watched closely nationwide.

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Health Plan Association says patients also need information about what doctors charge.
docs.snippet: The New York Health Plan Association says patients also need information about what doctors charge.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Veterans and Brain Disease,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (column, April 26):
docs.snippet: A neuroscientist discusses research suggesting that PTSD may be “physical” in nature.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''The Wrong Way to Stop Fake Drugs'' (Op-Ed, April 23), about Americans who buy medications abroad on the Internet, Roger Bate says ''health insurance companies should not be required to reimburse consumers for these drugs, because that would effectively import foreign governments' price controls into the United States and undermine American companies' research and development budgets.''
docs.snippet: A doctor asks why Americans should subsidize the cost of these drugs for the entire world.

headline.main: Are Banks Making Too Much Money From Fees?

docs.abstract: Do the fees banks charge customers need to be more closely regulated, or are they necessary for the health of the banks, and the economy?

docs.lead_paragraph: The slowing of the growth rate is partly explained by the recession, but evidence suggests that changes in the behavior of health care providers and consumers also partly account for it.

headline.seo: In Hopeful Sign, Health Spending Is Flattening Out
headline.main: In Hopeful Sign, Health Spending Is Flattening Out
headline.print_headline: In Hopeful Sign, Health Spending Is Flattening Out

docs.abstract: Growth of health spending has slowed substantially in the last few years, surprising experts and offering some fuel for optimism about the federal government’s long-term fiscal performance; trend is partly explained by the recession, but evidence suggests that changes in the behavior of health care providers and consumers are also partly responsible, meaning that lower rates of growth might persist even as the economy picks up.
docs.snippet: The slowing of the growth rate is partly explained by the recession, but evidence suggests that changes in the behavior of health care providers and consumers also partly account for it.
